I.  THE ENSUING INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
1.  The proposed investment program will enhance food security and rural economic growth 
in Punjab province.1 It will increase the agricultural production by developing a new seasonal 
irrigation system in Bhakkar, Jhang, Khushab, and Layyah districts of Punjab. The Greater Thal 
Canal (GTC) irrigation scheme will convert about 704,000 hectares (ha) of unproductive lands to 
irrigated lands. The scheme was partially constructed or is planned to be constructed by the 
government’s  fund.  The  proposed  investment  program  will  support  the  construction  of  the 
remaining parts covering about 440,000 ha to complete the development of the scheme and 
provide support to farmers for on-farm development and management.  
 
2.  Sector overview. It is estimated that an ever increasing population in Pakistan will require 
40%–50% additional food by 2025. However, agricultural productivity in Pakistan is well below 
global and even regional standards, due in large part to poor management of water resources.2 
Punjab is the country’s demographic and economic hub, containing around 100 million people 
and over 50% of national gross domestic product.3 Punjab’s overall contribution towards the 
agriculture  sector  of  the  country  is  estimated  at  more  than  80%,  and  therefore  improved 
agriculture productivity and production in Punjab significantly contributes to enhancing country’s 
food security.  
 
3.  Improved agricultural productivity and production can also have a direct positive impact 
on the people in Punjab who live in poverty and women working in the sector. Agriculture that 
generates about 40% of the provincial labor force remains the dominant source of income and 
livelihoods in rural Punjab. The incidence of poverty is higher in rural areas where agriculture 
remains the major source of income and livelihoods.  
 
4.  Pakistan is mostly semi-arid and arid, and thus, over 90% of agriculture output comes 
from irrigated agriculture. Out of 22.04 million ha of cultivated land in Pakistan, approximately 
18.80 million ha are irrigated, with the remainder being rain-fed (barani) agricultural areas.4 One 
of the fundamental strengths of Pakistan’s agriculture is the availability of water from the Indus 
Basin Irrigation System (IBIS), drawing from the Indus River and its tributaries. The IBIS covers 
over 14.9 million ha of farm land, consisting of three major multipurpose reservoirs, 23 barrages, 
headworks, and siphons, 12 inter-river link canals, and 45 major irrigation canal commands.5 Over 
70% of the cropped area of the IBIS is in Punjab. Farming in areas outside of the IBIS relies on 
rainfall or groundwater. Intensive pumping is lowering water tables in some areas by about one 
meter annually. This increases pumping costs and results in saltwater intrusion into aquifers. As 
a result, these areas suffer from frequent crop failures, low agricultural productivity, and land 
salinization, contributing to low farm incomes and slow agricultural growth. 
 
5.  Proposed interventions. The central part of Punjab is planned to be irrigated through the 
GTC irrigation scheme that will comprise the IBIS. It will draw water from the existing Chashma-
Jhelum link canal which diverts water from the Indus River to eastern areas. Water allocation for

the entire GTC irrigation scheme has been determined and approved in 1991 under the Pakistan 
Water Apportionment Accord that sets water resources allocation among four provinces. The 
government has completed a feasibility study and detailed engineering design for the entire 
scheme, and constructed the main canal and the first branch called Mankera (65 km) in 2010. 
The second branch called Choubara (73 km) is planned to be constructed by the provincial 
government from 2018. The construction of the remaining three branch canals has not been 
initiated, and therefore, out of 704,000 ha of the entire scheme, about 440,000 ha of land under 
these three branches remains excluded from the IBIS and low productive. 
 
6.  The proposed investment program will construct the three remaining branch canals, i.e. 
Dhingana (91 km), Mahmood (54 km) and Nurpur (58 km), and associated structures to provide 
a reliable irrigation water supply to 440,000 ha of the land during the monsoon (kharif) season 
from around April to October and will provide on-farm command area development support for 
the entire GTC irrigation scheme to enhance the on-farm and water management capacity of 
farmers. 
 
7.  The proposed intervention is likely take a phased approach applying a multitranche 
financing facility (MFF), although the most suitable financing modality will be examined during the 
project  preparation.  The  proposed  interventions  have  been  well  defined,  and  will  require 
significant investment of about $550 million covering about 440,000 ha of the irrigation area. On-
farm command area development support can be started only after having irrigation water in new 
irrigation canals. The MFF is expected to have two tranches. The first tranche will construct two 
new branch canals (Dhingana and Mahmood) with associated structures and will conduct on-farm 
command area development support in the existing branch canal areas (Mankera and Chaubara). 
Subsequently, under the second tranche, the remaining one branch (Nurpur) with associated 
structures  will  be  constructed  and  on-farm  command  area  development  supports  will  be 
conducted in the rest of the project area starting from the two branch areas that will be constructed 
under the first tranche.  
 
8.  The MFF also allows (i) strategic and systematic interventions that can facilitate longer-
term development and management planning of water resources including irrigation; and (ii) 
longer, more effective and strategic support for enhancing provincial-level institutional capacity, 
with a particular attention on the province’s strategy to transform the Punjab Irrigation Department 
(PID) to a water resources department.   
 
9.  The PID which will serve as the executing agency of the investment program has a long-
term plan to transfer from a traditional irrigation water deliverer to a water resources department 
that will comprehensively plan, develop and manage water resources for various water uses 
including water-related disasters. ADB’s Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA)6 
supports the PID for developing an action plan for the transformation and institutional capacity 
enhancement. As irrigation is the dominant water user, the investment program will be designed 
in due consideration of findings and outputs of the CDTA, and may be designed to implement the 
action plan to be proposed by the CDTA.  
 
10.  The due diligence for sector road map, policy framework, and governance-related issues 
were  carried  out  in  2006  when  the  Punjab  Irrigated  Agriculture  Investment  Program  was

prepared.7 The  sector  road  map  will  be  updated  during  the  preparation  of  the  proposed 
investment program, based on findings of the existing MFF through preparation of its completion

11.  Impacts, outcomes and outputs. The impacts of the proposed investment program will 
be aligned with: food security increased8 and rural poverty in Punjab reduced.9 The outcome will 
be agricultural production in the project area increased. The anticipated outputs are: (i) three 
branches of the GTC Irrigation System constructed that will be accomplished by the construction 
of 203 km of primary canals (i.e. Dhingana, Mahmood, and Nurpur branch canals), 970 km of 
secondary canals (i.e. distributaries), 246 km of tertiary canals (i.e. minors) and associated 
structures  to  convey  irrigation  water  to  the  project  area;  (ii)  farmer’s  on-farm  and  water 
management  capacity  improved  that  will  be  accomplished  by  community  mobilization  for 
formulating farmers’ organizations and water users’ associations, construction of water courses 
by the community contract, on-farm agriculture development support and capacity development 
training to farmers including crop diversification, high efficiency agriculture and appropriate water 
management; and (iii) institutional system for irrigation scheme management strengthened, 
including  an  improved  PID’s  knowledge  base  and  institutional  performance  in  monitoring, 
management and operation and management of irrigation schemes.  
 
12.  Tentative financing plan. An MFF is tentatively estimated at $440 million of ADB-
financing. The first tranche is envisaged for $300 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
and the remaining $140 million is envisaged for the second tranche. The total cost of the 
investment program and each tranche will be further assessed during the transaction technical 
assistance (TRTA). Financing in combination with concessional ordinary capital resources may 
be considered, depending on the fund availability.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
13.  The transaction TA will help the government prepare the investment program. A feasibility 
study and detailed engineering design has been completed by the government in 2008. The TRTA 
will verify the detailed design, update the existing cost estimates and feasibility study including 
economic and financial viability. The TRTA will formulate the project design as an MFF, or more 
appropriate financing modality, if any, that will include on-farm command area development 
support and institutional capacity strengthening. The TRTA will also conduct other project related 
due diligence like environmental and social safeguards, poverty and gender, financial and 
procurement risk assessments, risk assessment and management plan preparation, and climate 
risk vulnerability.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, of which $1.4 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff,  data  and  information  access,  logistical  support,  coordination  and  liaison  with  other 
government departments, and facilitation of consultation with stakeholders, and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture 
Division of Central and West Asia Department (CWER) will select, supervise and evaluate 
consultants. The PID will be the executing agency. The existing Project Management Office (PMO) 
– Canals under the PID led by the project director will serve as a TA focal, and assist and 
coordinate with TA consultants.
